7/7 For either classes, the barriers of entry are low, but the hurdles to a finished and solid product are high.
6/7 Either classes require a subject matter expertise or operations-specific experience by their creators or developers.
5/7 Either classes can have legal and contractual implications (or not).
4/7 Deterministic smart contracts are more like a finite business process + business logic meshed together.
3/7 Governed smart contracts can be self-modified according to governance rules and processes that are part of their design.
2/7 One could classify smart contracts as: 1/ Governed, or 2/ Deterministic.
1/7 Some thoughts on smart contracts and understanding them, in the context of blockchains.

the S&P figures show the earnings hit happening last year, the analyst (FactSet) figures lag and show it this year.
these were the two sectors that overwhelmingly accounted for last year's -11% earnings drop.
materials staged strong earnings recovery in Q2, and energy's losses a gradual shrinking (but still not positive).
q/q numbers suggest a positive inflection point has been reached, but sectoral breakdown is more mixed than before.
it's certainly true that 12-month trailing operating EPS is down -9.2% y/y ago, but that's cumulative w/base effect.
the base numbers are $25.86 operating, $23.35 reported for 2Q16, vs. $26.14 operating, $22.80 reported for 2Q15.
